section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need classroom objects of varying sizes and weights, such as a pencil, a mug, a doll, and a book.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Seesaw, we compared the sizes and weights of the characters.
In this activity, we will compare objects from our classroom. I will ask you to compare two objects at a time. You will tell me which one is bigger. Then, you will tell me which is heavier.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Compare Size Choose two objects, and call on a child to compare them by size. Encourage the child to place the objects side by side, and say which one is bigger.
Compare Weight Ask the child to compare the same two objects by weight. Encourage the child to hold one object in each hand and say which one feels heavier.
Repeat Ask another child to compare a different set of objects. Repeat until all children have had a chance to compare multiple sets of objects.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Was it easier to compare objects by size, or by weight? Which objects were the hardest to compare?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Discuss whether weight always correlated to size: Were the bigger objects also the heavier objects? Was that ever not true? (A book that is bigger than a mug, but thin and light; a book that is smaller than a stuffed animal, but dense; etc.)

Model comparing objects by placing them side by side for size, and holding one in each hand for weight. Speak aloud as you compare: This pencil is not as tall or as long as this book. The book is bigger! It’s easier to lift the pencil than the book. The book is heavier!
Challenge children to compare more than two objects at once and place them in order from biggest to smallest, then lightest to heaviest.

Review key vocabulary, such as small, big, heavy, and light. Remind children that the suffix -er means “more.” Use sentence clozes as necessary: The book is harder to hold up high. That means it is h . (heavier)

Choose objects of a similar or dull color. Children may find it easier to compare objects by size if they are not distracted by bright colors. Provide gloves for children to use as they hold the objects to compare them if they do not like the idea of touching them directly.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes and building blocks, specifically small cylinders and long, thin rectangles.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Seesaw, we talked about the importance of working together as a team.
In this activity, you and a partner will work as a team to build a seesaw out of building blocks. Then, you will practice balancing Connecting Cubes on it.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Build Give each set of partners a mix of building blocks and guide them to build a seesaw. (The simplest way to build a seesaw is to place a long, thin rectangular block on top of a short cylinder on its side.)

Balance Once each set of partners has created a seesaw, give them Connecting Cubes. Have children place varying amounts of Connecting Cubes on either side of their seesaw to balance it. Guide children to recognize that the same number of cubes must be placed on each side for the seesaw to balance.

Compare Ask partners to describe how they built their seesaw. Compare the sizes of seesaws created and the blocks used to create them: Was it easier to make a seesaw with a smaller block at the center and a longer block on top? Why do you think that is?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What was it like to work with your partner as a team? Did you reach your goal? What was difficult about working together? Did working together make it easier to reach your goal?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model building a seesaw using a long, thin rectangle and a small cylinder. Encourage children to work with their partner to copy your design.
Have children use Connecting Cubes for one side of the seesaw and Two-Color Counters for the other. Challenge them to find out how many counters are needed to balance one Connecting Cube.
Review key vocabulary, such as seesaw, team, and goal. Encourage children to use hand gestures and point to the blocks they want to build with as they work with their partners.
Have each pair work in a separate area, so that children don’t become distracted by what’s happening with the other pairs.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need a balance scale, Connecting Cubes, and various small objects from around the room. If you don’t have a balance scale, you can make one using two cups with holes for string, a piece of string, and a plastic hanger.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Seesaw, we talked about how we can tell which side of a seesaw is holding more weight. We also practiced counting one more or less in a group.

In this activity, we are going to use a balance scale to see which objects are heavier than others. A balance scale works like a seesaw: the side that is lighter goes up and the side that is heavier goes down. Then, we will add and take away one object from the scale at a time and see what happens.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Weigh Place a Connecting Cube on one side of the balance scale, and a classroom object on the other side. Ask children, Which weighs more? Which weighs less? How do you know? Repeat using other classroom objects, weighing each compared to the Connecting Cube.

Add and Remove Have children experiment by adding and removing objects and Connecting Cubes from the scale one at a time. Each time something new is added or removed, ask, How many are there on this side now? Which side has more objects? Encourage children to count the objects on both sides. Then ask, Which side is heavier?
Talk About Weighing Talk about weighing and counting objects: Which object was heaviest? Was one object always lighter than many objects? Does the order that we count objects in matter?

Have children focus on heavier and lighter. Place the classroom object on one side of the scale and one counting cube on the other. Guide children to respond using this frame: The is heavier than the . Repeat with each object.
Challenge children to first guess and then count the number of Connecting Cubes that will equal the weight of each classroom object so that the scale balances.
Review key vocabulary, such as more, less, weigh, add, and take away. Encourage children to count the objects on each side using their fingers, and point to the side that is heavier
Have children help you create the balance scale by threading the string through the cups. Then, have children use tweezers to place objects on and remove objects from the scale.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Material For this activity, you will need approximately ten Connecting Cubes for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Great Big Enormous Yuca, we counted who tried to pull up the enormous yuca.

In this activity, you will pretend to plant yuca! I will give each of you ten Connecting Cubes to use as yuca plants. I will tell you how many you need to plant, and how many to pull up for dinner. Then, we will count how many yuca we have in all.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Plant Give each child ten Connecting Cubes. Let’s all plant five yuca to start. Guide children to place five connecting cubes in a row on the table in front of them. Let’s count them again to make sure we have five! Have children count the cubes in a different order.

Dinner Time Tell a child to “pull up” one yuca plant to eat for dinner. Guide the child to remove one cube. How many yuca are left? Ask the child to count the cubes in a different order to confirm the amount.

Plant More Tell another child to plant one more yuca. Guide the child to place a sixth cube in line. How many yuca are there now? Guide the child to count the cubes in a different order to confirm the amount.
Repeat Continue to tell children to “pull up” or “plant” yuca one at a time, always asking how many there are and suggesting that children count the cubes in a different order to make sure.
Talk About Amounts Remind children that they started out with five yuca plants. Ask, Do you have more, less, or the same amount of yuca now? How can you tell?

Count the “yuca” along with children, showing that the same amount is counted regardless of the counting order. Start with planting (adding) new cubes, and move to “pulling up” (taking away) as children are ready.

Have children “pull up” and “plant” more than one Connecting Cube at a time. Challenge children to pull up or plant cubes to reach a certain number: You have two yuca, but you will need five yuca for dinner tonight! How many more do you need to plant?

Review key vocabulary, such as pull up, more, less, same, amount, yuca and plant. Have children indicate how many yuca they have by saying the number, showing the number using their fingers, or pointing to the numeral card with the right number.
Have children use their whole bodies to pretend to pull hard like the characters in the chart whenever they “pull up” a cube, and pretend to dig in the ground when they “plant” a cube.
